prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UDF 850-micron mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A mosaic of 115 pointings covering the Hubble Ultra Deep Field, with beams spaced by 0.75 FWHM

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To achieve the best possible sensitivity we will use the dual polarisation mode. Although this is primarily a continuum proposal, we have considered carefully whether to use a single frequency setting or cover all of Band 7. We have decided to stay at a single frequency to maximise the significance of any individual CO or CII line detections. Even with this single frequency setting, we expect ~100 objects with spectroscopic redshifts to have a CO line at a known expected frequency within our observed bands, thus still allowing line-stacking experiments which will break new ground.

We request a spatial resolution of 0.7 arcsec, because, while the high angular resolution delivered by ALMA is essential to avoid being limited by source confusion, this is a detection experiment and we also wish to avoid significantly resolving out any flux in the faintest galaxies in the field (which have a typical half-light radius ~ 0.1-0.2 arcsec). 0.7 arcsec also matches the resolution of our current Cycle-1 1.3-mm image of the HUDF, and having matched angular resolution will be invaluable in simplifying the joint analysis of the two images.

As justified and explained in the main science case, our aim is to make an 850-micron continuum map of the Hubble Ultra Deep Field (HUDF) that matches the area coverage and spatial resolution of our (hopefully soon to be completed) ALMA Cycle-1 1.3-mm mosaic, and reaches an rms noise level 2.3 times greater (in order to ensure effective complementarity in detection levels in the two images out to high redshift).
REQUESTED SENSITIVITY: We request a continuum noise level per beam of 0.07 mJy at ~850 microns. As explained in the science case, this noise level is set to 'match' the 1.3-mm noise level of 0.03 mJy targeted in our Cycle-1 1.3mm mosaic (that was set to detect dust-enshrouded star-formation rates of down to ~ 25 solar masses per year). By 'match' we mean that the flux limits are set to achieve equivalent detections for a source which displays an observed SED which rising proportional to frequency squared between the two bands (ie Rayleigh-Jeans tail).
As shown in Fig. 4 of the attached science case, in practice, for a 35 K modified blackbody the result is predicted equivalent significance detections at both frequencies at redshift z ~ 4. At lower redshifts our 850-micron image will be more sensitive, while the 1.3-mm image will remain more sensitive at higher redshifts (unless, of course, high-redshift dust is warmer).
Setting the noise level at 850 microns at 0.07 mJy has the additional attraction that it yields a 2-sigma non detection limit equivalent to the 5-sigma limit at 1.3-mm, meaning that 850 non detections of 1.3-mm detected sources will still be useful out to extreme redshifts z ~ 10 (see bottom panel of Fig. 4).
IMAGING: A full imaging mosaic is requested because the expected surface density of detectable 850-micron sources is significantly greater than one per primary beam. Our simulations based on the known photometric redshifts and UV star-formation rates of the ~3000 galaxies in the HUDF HST imaging suggest we will detect ~200-300 sources at > 5-sigma in this planned 850-micron image, ~ twice the number predicted in the 1.3-mm Cycle-1 image because of the extra star-formation rate sensitivity achievable at 850 microns at z = 0 - 4 (see Fig. 4).
CALIBRATION: Default
BANDPASS ACCURACY: Standard
SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS: None
DATA RATE: Normal
TOTAL TIME REQUEST = 1.03 days (including overheads)

Only with complete coverage of the 4 sq arcmin of the HUDF can we fully exploit the existing optical-infrared data in the HUDF to perform stacking analyses in the ALMA 850-micron image, as well as matching the coverage of our Cycle-1 1.3-mm image. The size of the HUDF is well matched to the Cycle-3 constraints on mosaic size (150 max) because, using 0.75 FWHM beam spacing (as in our Cycle-1 1.3-mm proposal) we can achieve the required complete coverage in 115 pointings (see Fig. 3 in the science case). We stress that ~0.75 beam spacing is perfectly effective for point-source detection (this is standard practice in radio astronomy, and is in any case already approved for our Cycle-1 program), and it enables us to efficiently achieve the required complete coverage with less than 5% variation in imaging depth in across the image.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Completion of UDF 1.3mm mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We include this second science goal to complete our Cycle-1 1.3-mm mosaic of the the Hubble Ultra Deep Field (currently 59% complete according to the project tracker) if it is not completed in Cycle-2. We request only the currently missing fraction of integration time, and are of course happy to drop this additional science goal if the Cycle-1 1.3-mm mosaic is completed before the end of Cycle 2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To achieve the best possible sensitivity we will use the dual polarisation mode. Although this is primarily a continuum proposal, we have considered carefully whether to use a single frequency setting or cover all of Band 6. We have decided to stay at a single frequency to maximise the significance of any individual CO or CII line detections. Even with this single frequency setting, we expect ~100 objects with spectroscopic redshifts to have a CO line at a known expected frequency within our observed bands thus still allowing line-stacking experiments which will break new ground.

We request a spatial resolution of 0.7 arcsec because, while the high angular resolution delivered by ALMA is essential to avoid being limited by source confusion, this is a detection experiment and we also wish to avoid significantly resolving out any flux in the faintest galaxies in the field (which have a typical half-light radius ~ 0.1-0.2 arcsec). 0.7 arcsec also matches the resolution of the data taken to date in our rolled over Cycle-1 1.3-mm image, which according to the project tracker is 59% complete, and obviously we wish to complete the image at a consistent resolution if at all possible.

As justified and explained in the main science case and the original Cycle-1 proposal, our aim is to complete the approved 1.3-mm image of the HUDF (2012.1.00173.S) to the requested depth of 30 micro-Jy rms at 1.3-mm (should this not be achieved by the end of Cycle-2). This is necessary both to achieve the goals of the Cycle-1 program, and to maximise the power of the new Cycle-3 850-micron proposal for the same field.
REQUESTED SENSITIVITY: The sensitivity goal of the 1.3-mm image remains unchanged, at 0.03 mJy rms, in order to achieve a 4-sigma detection of a high-redshift galaxy with a dust-enshrouded SFR ~ 25 solar masses per year. Re-running the expoure time calculations with Cycle-3 ALMA, and assuming the project tracker is correct in reporting that 59% of the original exposure time request has now been completed (although we have yet to receive any actual data), we calculate that an additional 7.7 hours of ALMA time (including overheads) will be required to complete the originally requested 1.3-mm image (should no more data be taken before the end of Cycle-2). We note that, due to ALMA's decision to move Band-6 to slightly higher frequencies since Cycle-1, 53 pointings are now required rather than the original 45, but this will not adversely affect the final image.
IMAGING: A full imaging mosaic is requested because the expected surface density of detectable 1.3-mm sources is significantly greater than one per primary beam. Our simulations based on the known photometric redshifts and UV star-formation rates of the ~3000 galaxies in the HUDF HST imaging suggest we will detect ~100-200 sources in the final 1.3-mm image.
CALIBRATION: Default
BANDPASS ACCURACY: Standard
SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS: None
DATA RATE: Normal
TOTAL TIME REQUEST = 7.7 hours (including overheads)

Only with complete coverage of the 4 sq arcmin of the HUDF can we fully exploit the existing optical-infrared data in the HUDF to perform stacking analyses in the ALMA 1.3-mm image. As in the data taken to date in our Cycle-1 program, we propose to keep using ~0.75 FWHM beam spacing, as this is perfectly effective for point-source detection, and enables us to efficiently achieve the required complete coverage with less than 5% variation in imaging depth in across the image (see Fig. 3 in the science case).

Our approved Cycle-1 1.3 mm mosaic of the HUDF was carried over into Cycle 2, and according to the project tracker is currently 59% complete. We are therefore requesting the remaining 41% of the integration time required to complete this mosaic (utilising the updated total time estimate). We will of course be happy to see this dropped if the Cycle-1 1.3mm mosaic is completed before the end of Cycle 2.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Despite recent advances, the star-formation history of the Universe remains poorly determined during the first ~3 Gyr (z>2). This is because we lack direct measurements of the dust obscuration in typical high-z galaxies (as revealed by HST), due to the confusion-limited sensitivity of single-dish sub-mm telescopes. Only ALMA can deliver sub-mm imaging of the necessary sensitivity and resolution to bridge the gap and resolve this key issue.
We thus propose the first deep ALMA 850-micron image of the Hubble Ultra Deep Field (HUDF). This image will complement our Cycle-1 1.3-mm mosaic of the HUDF, allowing us to probe down to obscured star-formation rates SFR~10 solar masses per year at z~2, and providing key constraints on dust temperature (and hence SFR and dust/gas mass) out to z~10.
An 850-micron mosaic in the HUDF is justified by the anticipated source density, and its scientific value will be maximised by co-locating it with our Cycle-1 1.3-mm map in the HUDF, where the optical-IR data will remain unsurpassed for the foreseeable future.
Our Cycle-1 1.3-mm mosaic is reportedly 59% complete, so we also include an additional science goal (7.7 hr) to complete it if necessary.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals:
2012.1.00173.S An ALMA 1.3-mm image of the Hubble Ultra Deep Field James Dunlop (59% complete on Project Tracker)
2013.1.01154.S A deep ALMA 850-micron image of the Hubble Ultra Deep Field: completing our view of cosmic star-formation history James Dunlop
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
